text: hello and welcome it's march 13th 2024 and we're here in active inference guest stream number 75.1 active inference with empathy mechanism for socially behaved artificial agent in diverse situations with tada yuki matsumura kanako isekai and hiroyuki mizuno so thank you all for joining and looking forward to hearing your talk and discussion
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Thank you for inviting us to such a good opportunity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm Kadeki Matsumura and my co-researcher Kaneko and Hiroyuki also joined this discussion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We are developing AI, especially AI which is inspired by human-like autonomous agents to make social artificial agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: recently we published a paper related to the idea in journal of a life the title is active influence with empathy mechanism for socially behaved artificial agent in diverse situations first i'd like to explain the paper this is the motivation of this research
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The title of the paper shows the motivation of this research is to develop socially behaved artificial agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We believe that sociality will become an important point to apply AI in our daily life.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The difficulty to realize social agents is that an appropriate social behavior depends on a given situation or culture.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As described in the bottom figure, we have sociality even in just walking case.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, how fast should we walk or how much distance from others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if we implement sociality with rule-based program, we have to design a lot of magic number for each situation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is impossible because there are a wide variety of situations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Due to this, unified mechanism or principle for social behavior is required.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is the challenge.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We assume that we humans have such unified behavior model because we humans can behave socially in diverse situations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we develop social engines inspired by human behavior models, namely, free energy principle and active influence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this research, we use the active influence for the basis of the behavior model of human life agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As you know, active inference is a concept proposed in the free energy principle.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And free energy principle is a unified hypothesis for our cognitive activities.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the FAP, our cognitive activities are explained by such.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But we have internal models for predicting future of surrounding environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Second, we always try to minimize the free energy of the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Free energy is defined by this equation, and it intuitively represents uncertainty of prediction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The interesting point of the FEP is that the internal model inferred not only the hidden state, but also actions for the agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is, the action to be taken is the action which minimizes the free energy of the agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is the basic idea of active inference, as I understand it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Intentional actions also can be explained in the active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this case, we consider expected free energy, which is the free energy for the future state
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When considering multi-time step ahead, expected energy at multi-time step ahead is considered as described in the right figure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Based on the expected free energy for each action, the distribution of the action is determined such that the smaller the expected free energy, the higher the probability of selection.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When we consider intentional behavior, intentions are considered as requirements of future observations, and rewards according to the future observation are encoded into the last equation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are my understanding of the standard active inference and the behavior model of the human life agent based on it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We extend this active inference to generate the social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The idea of the extension is explained using a situation in which there are two agents called I and other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The agent called I is the subject of the action in this explanation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The biological agent under the X3 inference makes predictions about the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and takes some action to minimize the uncertainty of the prediction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this figure, I predict future behavior of the other because the other is an environment, or I. Namely, I act to reduce uncertainty for the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So far, this is a standard active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here, if we consider that the other is also a biological agent, we can assume that the other also acts under the active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Under this idea, we can assume that the other also predicts the future behavior of me, and the other tries to reduce the uncertainty of the prediction about me in this situation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this understanding, we notice that our action can reduce not only our own free energy, but also that of the others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is because my action affects not only my own free energy, but also the free energy of the others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If I can predict other's prediction for me, I can act to reduce the free energy of the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is the idea of the proposed extension of the active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We extend FEP and active inference from an individual idea to a collective idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As described in this image of concept,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The agent marginally shares the brain, and they try to minimize the free energy of the shared brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To release the free energy for the shared brain, we act not only for me, but also for the others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because of this action for others,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We expect that this idea can be used to generate social behavior, which is a behavior for us, not only for me or only for you.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To realize this idea, it is necessary to predict other's prediction about myself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is implemented based on the mirror system and simulation theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Hypothesis for the mechanism of empathy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the mirror system and simulation theory, it is said that we understand others by simulating others by own bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We consider the idea of using our own body to simulate others as using our internal model to infer other predictions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The overview of the mechanism is described in the figure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The agent has the internal model to predict future observations for his own observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Moreover, we use the same internal model to predict others' predictions about myself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Although the model is the same, the input to the model is changed to the observations of the others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For this,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the process of inference of other observations is included.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, when the observation is an image, novel view synthesis, which is the problem of generating images from different viewpoints, can be used.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the other case, as we will discuss in the following evaluation,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: if the observation is the location of the agent coordinate transformation transformation can be used based on this inference procedures the expected free energy is extended as describing this equation as with the encoding of intentional behavior we add a term to the first term that is intention
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: to respond to the expectation of others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If there are multiple others, the sum of each other's expectation is considered.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We call the proposed idea empathic active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We evaluate the proposed idea using the control task of an autonomous mobile agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the evaluation, multiple agents move to each target point.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The shortest paths of each agent intersect each other, and agents are required to take collision avoidance behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The player, the red agent, is controlled by the proposed method, and the other agents are controlled by the social force model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Social force model is a simple social walking model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Roughly said, it is a dynamics model in which the walking speed and direction are determined by two forces.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first one is driving force to the goal and the second is repulsive force from the others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this evaluation, the weight of the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The weight of these two types of forces are changed to evaluate different situations where two types of others, selfish or altruistic others,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When the force to the goal is larger than the force from others, the agents take behavior in selfish.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other hand, the force from the others is larger than the force to the goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The agents take behavior in altruistic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are examples of the behavior of others under the control of the social force model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The player, let's say, randomly moves, and the others, green, blue, or orange, are moved with social force mode.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The top picture is an example for selfish others, and the bottom picture is an example for altruistic others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The difference is from the difference of the magnitude of the two forces.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As you can see from the figures,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When others are characteristic, the other will take the path which has more margin with others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The setup for the player is simply described.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The action space is defined in discrete space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Movement for 5 directions and weight current position, totally 6 actions is assumed.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A simple variational autoencoder-like model is used to the internal model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The model is trained in an offline manner.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The model is used to predict the expected free energy for each action.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First, the evaluation results when there is only one other besides the player are shown.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We discussed the sociality of the agent based on the four B points.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first one, if my travel distance is longer, it is social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the second, if the other travel distance is shorter, it is social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The third, if the minimum margin among agents is larger, it is social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If the inequality of the travel distance is smaller, it is social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Inequality means that the difference in travel distance among agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As a comparison, we also showed the result of the standard active inference cases.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The two figures in the left side are the case when the others are selfish.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this case, the player with the standard active inference moves straight to the destination because the player acts optimally only for its own purpose.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other hand, the proposed agent moves to appoint the other as well as the other because the player predicts
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The other expects the player to avoid collision, and the player tries to respond to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As a result of taking this detour path, the sociality of the behavior is increased.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Namely, the travel distance of the player increased compared to that of the standard active inference case.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: At the same time, the travel distance of the others decrease and the minimum distance between the player and the other increase.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In addition, the inequality of the difference in travel distance is decreased.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Next, the case where a characteristic is shown on the right two figures.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this case, the same tendency is observed.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: as in the case where the other is selfish.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But the player moved a path with a larger margin to the other compared to the case of the selfish other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This result indicates that the proposed agent can behave in a social manner that is beneficial to the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: even if the results are disadvantageous to itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: An important point is that the difference of the social behavior does not depend on any reward designing as in reinforcement learning.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Namely, the sociality depends on the character of the other around the player.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The other around the player is not just an obstacle for the agent,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but as a teacher for the social manner.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the case where three others besides the player a similar result in the altruistic as a case.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Namely, the travel distance of the player is increased and that of others are decreased, and the minimum margin is increased and inequality of the travel distance is decreased.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other hand, in the case of selfish others, a collision occurs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It may be due to high density in the center point.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this case, the proposed agent can avoid collision by weighting the crossing of others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I repeat the important point.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is no need to design reward or penalty for sociality in each situation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A social behavior realized by responding to the other expectation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, I would like to summarize the explanation of the paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As I said at the first slide,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The motivation of this research is to develop a unified mechanism for social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The answer for the motivation is that running an internal model to predict the future behavior of others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is same as standard free energy principle or table inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Moreover, predict others' expectations about me with the same internal model, and try to respond to the others' expectations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This process makes a cyclic process, and it encourages the agents to behave like sounding others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because due to the mirror system, others' expectations to me are the same
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: came to my expectation to others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This mechanism encouraged the agent to behave like surrounding others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This summary shows our idea for what is social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The answer is that social behavior is a behavior like surrounding others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The others are not obstacles but teachers for social behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This also means that we are teachers of AI or robots for the future society.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's all.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is the explanation of the paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'd like to discuss about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you.
